poem:
**Breaking Light on New Pages**

Tales tethered to the land's old bruise,  
liquid words flow from a fresh pen.  
In shadows, history sighs—  
a breath still warm.  
  
Half-light stories written,  
where milkmen and pale hands linger.  
New verses emerge under the weight  
of yesterday's perpetual whisper.  
Barefoot, this morning's grass hums  
beneath the touch of Ní Chuinn.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Every One Still Here by Liadan Ní Chuinn review – an extraordinary debut The literature of the Troubles is a rich one, from Seamus Heaney’s North (1975), Jennifer Johnston’s Shadows on Our Skin (1977) and Bernard MacLaverty’s Cal (1983), to Eoin McNamee’s Resurrection Man (1994), Anna Burns’s Booker-winning Milkman (2018), and Louise Kennedy’s Trespasses (2022). The latest addition to the corpus, a slim debut story collection by nonbinary Northern Irish writer Liadan Ní Chuinn, shares". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Every One Still Here by Liadan Ní Chuinn review – an extraordinary debut The literature of the Troubles is a rich one, from Seamus Heaney’s North (1975), Jennifer Johnston’s Shadows on Our Skin (1977) and Bernard MacLaverty’s Cal (1983), to Eoin McNamee’s Resurrection Man (1994), Anna Burns’s Booker-winning Milkman (2018), and Louise Kennedy’s Trespasses (2022). The latest addition to the corpus, a slim debut story collection by nonbinary Northern Irish writer Liadan Ní Chuinn, shares
